importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Originally planned launch date for Lamborghini's all-electric Urus successor, which was later shelved.
Planned phase-out date for new petrol and diesel car sales in the EU and UK, which may be extended due to industry lobbying and low-volume manufacturer exemptions.
Date of the article's publication, when Lamborghini's leadership announced continued use of internal combustion engines for at least the next decade.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which Lamborghini will continue using internal combustion engines, with a decision on the Lanzador model expected within the next month.

keyTakeAways: Lamborghini's CEO, Stephan Winkelmann, has stated that customers still desire the sound and emotion of internal combustion engines, leading to a decision to delay full electrification.
The company will decide within the next month whether its new Lanzador model will be an all-electric vehicle or a plug-in hybrid.
Lamborghini's original plan for an all-electric Urus successor, set for 2029, has been shelved and now expected no earlier than 2035.
The brand's approach contrasts with Ferrari's push toward full electrification, with Ferrari unveiling its all-electric Elettrica model planned for next year.
Lamborghini, as a low-volume manufacturer, is exempt from the EU and UK bans on petrol and diesel cars due to selling fewer than 2,500 units annually.
Despite being socially responsible, Lamborghini claims its environmental impact is minimal due to its low sales volume.

namedEntities.name: Lamborghini
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A luxury Italian supercar manufacturer, currently owned by the Volkswagen Group, with three main models: Temerario, Revuelto, and Urus.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central subject of the article, representing a major automotive brand that is choosing to delay full electrification in favor of hybrid power and traditional engines.

namedEntities.name: Stephan Winkelmann
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief executive of Lamborghini, who has publicly stated the company's decision to retain internal combustion engines for at least the next decade.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The key spokesperson who articulated customer demand and strategic business decisions related to engine types and electrification timelines.

namedEntities.name: Volkswagen Group
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The parent company of Lamborghini, which owns and oversees the brand's operations and strategic direction.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides context for Lamborghini’s corporate structure and alignment with broader automotive industry trends under a larger conglomerate.

namedEntities.name: Ferrari
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Italian luxury car brand and rival to Lamborghini, which is advancing plans for full electrification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights a key contrast in strategic direction between Lamborghini and Ferrari, illustrating divergent approaches to electric vehicle adoption in the luxury segment.

namedEntities.name: Ferrari Elettrica
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Ferrari's planned all-electric model, set for unveiling next year, with driving characteristics described as emotionally resonant with customers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a direct competitor to Lamborghini's decision to delay electrification, emphasizing a contrasting future path in the luxury automotive market.

namedEntities.name: Urus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A luxury SUV model available in both plug-in hybrid and conventional petrol versions, currently the top-selling Lamborghini model.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A flagship model that originally had an all-electric successor planned, now delayed to 2035, illustrating Lamborghini’s pivot in electrification strategy.

namedEntities.name: Temerario
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A supercar model that is a plug-in hybrid, combining a petrol engine with electric motors and capable of short all-electric runs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: An example of Lamborghini's current hybrid strategy, showing customer demand for both performance and electric capability in limited ranges.

namedEntities.name: Revuelto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A supercar model that is a plug-in hybrid, offering all-electric mode for short distances.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another example of Lamborghini's current hybrid models, reinforcing the brand's continued use of hybrid technology in high-performance vehicles.

namedEntities.name: Fenomeno
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A limited edition super-sports car with a top speed exceeding 215mph, only 30 units will be built at a cost of at least €3 million each.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates Lamborghini’s commitment to exclusivity and performance, which continues to appeal to customers who value traditional engine experiences.

namedEntities.name: Lanzador
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new model planned by Lamborghini, currently undecided between all-electric and plug-in hybrid configurations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The focal point of the company's upcoming strategic decision, symbolizing the future direction of Lamborghini’s product development.

namedEntities.name: European Union
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional governing body setting regulations on new car sales, with a 2035 ban on petrol and diesel vehicles.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The regulatory environment driving the debate over electrification, with potential extensions due to industry lobbying and low-volume exemptions.

namedEntities.name: United Kingdom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A national jurisdiction with similar vehicle emissions regulations and exemptions for low-volume manufacturers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides a legal context where Lamborghini’s low sales volume allows it to remain on the market with internal combustion engines beyond 2035.

namedEntities.name: CO2 Emissions
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key environmental concern driving global automotive policy changes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The backdrop of environmental responsibility, with Lamborghini arguing its low sales volume limits its environmental impact despite being a luxury brand.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Lamborghini, under CEO Stephan Winkelmann, is choosing to delay its full transition to electric vehicles, citing strong customer demand for the sound and emotion of internal combustion engines. The company will decide within the next month whether its new Lanzador model will be all-electric or a plug-in hybrid, reversing earlier plans for an all-electric Urus successor scheduled for 2029. Lamborghini’s strategy contrasts with Ferrari’s push for an all-electric model, the Elettrica, set for launch next year. As a low-volume manufacturer, Lamborghini is exempt from EU and UK bans on petrol and diesel cars, allowing it to continue selling internal combustion engine vehicles at least until 2035, despite acknowledging environmental responsibility.
title: Lamborghini swerves away from all-electric future
